title: 105_hr1330
content: The "American Family Privacy Act of 1997" restricts access to Social Security account statement information, personal earnings and benefits estimate statement information, and tax return information of an individual. The "American Family Privacy Act of 1997" prohibits Federal officers or employees from making certain personal financial information available online without written consent. Additionally, access to social security account statements, personal earnings and benefits estimates, and tax return information of individuals is restricted without their consent. The "Commission on Privacy of Government Records" is established with 9 members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, and Senate majority leader within 60 days of the Act's enactment. The President designates the Chairman of the Commission. The Commission on Privacy of Government Records consists of 9 members appointed for life by the President, who investigates the protection and privacy of tax information and other personal data in Government records. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission on Privacy of Government Records investigates procedures for providing access to information without compromising privacy. They are required to submit a report to the President and Congress by April 15, 1998, with findings, conclusions, and recommendations for action. The Commission has the power to hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, administer oaths, and obtain information from government departments and agencies. The Commission on Privacy of Government Records has the authority to request information from US departments and agencies to carry out its duties. It also has immunity for witnesses and can contract with government and private entities for goods and services. The Commission meets at the call of the Chairman or a majority of its members, with a quorum of five members required. The Commission on Privacy of Government Records requires a quorum of five members to hold hearings. Any member or agent can take actions authorized by the Commission. Members are entitled to receive pay for their duties, based on the Executive Schedule. Full-time officers or employees of the US government cannot receive additional pay. The Commission on Privacy of Government Records requires a quorum of five members for hearings. Members cannot receive additional pay, allowances, or benefits. They are entitled to travel expenses and can appoint staff without following certain regulations. Staff pay can be determined independently. The Commission may use postal and printing services, procure experts and consultants, and request staff from federal agencies. The Commission can request personnel from federal agencies to assist in its duties and accept gifts or property to support its work. Gifts of money or proceeds from sales are deposited in the Treasury for disbursement. The Commission will terminate within 60 days of submitting its report to the President. The Commission will terminate no later than 60 days after submitting its report to the President and Congress.
